headline: Footwear brands including Nike and Adidas ask Trump for tariff exemption
summary: The Footwear Distributors & Retailers of America trade group (FDRA) urged U.S. President Donald Trump to exempt shoes from reciprocal tariffs in a letter signed by makers including Nike, Adidas America and Skechers. WHY IT'S IMPORTANT The FDRA letter, dated April 29, was signed by 76 footwear companies such as Deckers Brands, Capri Holdings, Under Armour, and VF Corp. The trade group said that the industry already faces significant levies, including children's shoes, which often have rates of 20%, 37.5%, or higher, before accounting for the new tariffs.

headline: Nike, Adidas, footwear brands call on Trump for tariff exemptions
summary: Apparel brands Nike (NKE), Adidas (ADDYY), and Skechers (SKX) are among 76 footwear companies asking President Trump for tariff exemptions. Market Domination hosts Josh Lipton and Julie Hyman discuss how these new tariffs could worsen the situation. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Market Domination here.

headline: NIKE (NYSE:NKE) Announces US$0.40 Quarterly Dividend for Class A & B Shares
summary: NIKE (NYSE:NKE) recently announced a quarterly cash dividend of $0.40 per share, slated for payout on July 1, 2025. Last week, the company's stock experienced a 3% decline, contrasting with the broader market's rise of nearly 2%, which was buoyed by strong employment data and easing trade tensions between the U.S. and China. Despite a generally positive market tone, NIKE's dip might reflect investor reactions to its earlier dividend affirmation, as major market indices continued their upward...

headline: Why Nike Stock Dropped 11% in April
summary: Nike is already experiencing sales declines due to customers cutting spending.  Nike is the top-selling activewear company in the world, and it has strong brand power.  Nike (NYSE: NKE) stock dropped 11% in April, according to data provided by S&P Global Market Intelligence.

headline: 3 Consumer Stocks Facing Headwinds
summary: Most consumer discretionary businesses succeed or fail based on the broader economy. This sensitive demand profile can cause discretionary stocks to plummet when macro uncertainty enters the fray, and over the past six months, the industry has shed 8.3%. This drawdown was worse than the S&P 500’s 2% loss.
